Award.AwardTitle: Technological Education for the Rural Community (TERC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hopkinsville Community College serves a rural, five-county region in southern Kentucky and northern Tennessee that is home to over 70 manufacturing companies that consistently have difficulty hiring qualified employees to fill technology related positions. The Technological Education for the Rural Community (TERC) project is developing innovative educational pathways for technological education at the community college level to influence employability in technical fields within the rural community. TERC utilizes portable, personalized instructional methods to address identified barriers including inflexible work schedules, extended time between high school and college, and poor academic preparation. In particular, access issues and low mathematics comprehension are being addressed by utilizing hybrid delivery systems and contextualized mathematics and engineering coursework.

The hybrid program incorporates problem based learning (PBL) centered on industry designed curriculum standards making coursework relevant to the highly technical workplace. The project uses a fusion of delivery models for students who work and cannot attend traditional college classes. Didactic content is being delivered via the Internet and preloaded content on portable media. Lab work is facilitated through one-on-one instruction in an open lab environment with hands-on applications and models developed through the project. TERC uses targeted marketing for underrepresented groups and the rural student at regional business and career fairs highlighting student successes. Project evaluation and assessment activities are collecting data on the incorporation of contextualized mathematics as a means of improving the pathway for rural and underrepresented students into entry level manufacturing jobs. The use of a hybrid delivery model is being measured by both comparing the students enrolled in a traditional course with those enrolled in the hybrid sections, and by comparing retention and student perceptions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Technological Education for the Rural Community (TERC) project developed pathways for rural and underrepresented students to attain credentials leading to jobs in advanced manufacturing. The project identified weaknesses such as low comprehension in areas of mathematics that precluded students from completing the program. Hands-on applications and supplemental instruction were incorporated into the mathematics curriculum to assist students in skill development and grasping the relevance of the math needed for their program and career. The supplemental materials such as fractions, decimals, percentages and basic algebra were added to allow remediation for adult learners who have been out of school for years and had either forgotten basic math skills or who never learned them. Students also learn basic skills like how to use a tape measure when doing hands-on problems. This approach of supplementing material and hands-on real world problems is a model that impacts students in more than just advanced manufacturing but also in STEM education. Projects and ideas from the grant were showcased to math educators at state and nationwide mathematical conferences.   

Another barrier to student success is access to high speed internet to complete coursework and review materials from home. Kentucky does not have the infrastructure to support high speed internet in all areas nor can all students afford them who do have access. Thumb drives with content from coursework were provided to assist them. Additionally lab time was incorporated into the program so students could complete assignments prior to leaving campus. Students were afforded more opportunities to ask questions of the instructor and get homework help during class time than would otherwise be available. Students spent more time doing the math rather than watching the instructor work problems. A math lab tutor was also available to students to get help during the afternoon and evenings.

Targeted marketing through posters, handbills, social media and mailed flyers were used for awareness of the program opportunities for women, minorities, veterans, and other marginalized groups. Recruitment materials showcased women and minority students emphasizing the opportunity that is available to them. Veterans were also recruited into the program to assist their transition from active duty to the civilian job market where high demand manufacturing jobs exist. Recruitment efforts were also conducted at rural and city high schools, veteran?s center, alternative schools, minority organizations, and substance abuse programs among others.

Originally the program was offered as a traditional college program but with Kentucky?s move to implement a career pathway for students in advanced manufacturing the TERC program seamlessly fused the grant?s purpose with a new cohort model. Students in the program work three days a week for a local or regional employer and attend school the other two days. Learners have the same classes with their cohort and are able to help each other out. Built in study groups naturally form between students in cohorts in the TERC program. This model moves students together through the program graduating with an Associate?s in Applied Science in five semesters. The cohort allows students the opportunity to make money while achieving a degree in a very brief timeline which is ideal for students with financial responsibilities that may not finish with a longer term program. The cohort model used in the TERC program can be adjusted to fit the needs of other STEM programs and impact STEM educational attainment and goals.
